intro: Pleurothallis brittoniana, commonly known as the Britton's orchid, is a species native to the tropical regions of Central and South America. It belongs to the Orchidaceae family and is characterized by its delicate, often fragrant flowers. The plant typically grows as an epiphyte, attaching itself to trees in humid, shaded environments. Its inflorescence usually consists of a few to several small, colorful flowers that bloom during the wet season. The leaves are usually lance-shaped and arranged in a compact rosette, aiding in moisture retention in its natural habitat.
